Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Using mobile devices to study craving, emotions, and attention in Korean smokers
Award.AbstractNarration:
Decades of policy and clinical interventions have led to declining cigarette smoking rates in Western countries. Worldwide, however, the number of smokers is actually increasing, and cigarette smoking remains a leading preventable cause of disease and death. In Korea, 40 to 50% of men and 4 to 8% of women self-identify as smokers, with an increasing trend for female smokers. People from different cultures may differ in their smoking behaviors, and Ecological Momentary Assessment (EMA) is an innovative methodology for examining smoking behavior in the natural environment. EMA researchers often leverage the power of mobile technologies (e.g., smartphones). However, most EMA studies have been conducted in non-Asian regions. This project will investigate if EMA methods can be feasibly applied with South Korean smokers and generate valid data. The project will be hosted jointly by Dr. Se-hoon Joeng at Korea University and Dr. Sooyeon Suh at Sungshin Women's University, both in Seoul, South Korea. Dr. Jeong is a psychologist specializing in mobile technology use and health behaviors and Dr. Suh is a clinical health psychologist with expertise in the interaction of behavioral and psychological factors with physical health.

In this 1-week observational EMA study, each participant will be given a mobile device at the first lab visit to carry around with them as they go about their daily lives. The device will prompt them at random times (random assessments; RAs) to complete brief questions and a reaction time test. These RAs will assess negative and positive affect, craving, culturally-specific attitudes, attention to smoking cues, and number of cigarettes smoked. The first specific aim will examine the feasibility of EMA research, such as participant compliance to complete RAs, in Korean smokers. The second specific aim will examine mood, cognitive performance, and behaviors in Korean smokers. Predictor variables will include demographic variables, technology readiness, cultural variables, mindfulness, and smoking dependence. Ultimately, a greater understanding of the cultural influences on smoking behaviors may improve smoking cessation interventions for this population. This NSF EAPSI award supports the research of a U.S. graduate student and is funded in collaboration with the National Research Foundation of Korea.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As of 2015, scientists remain limited in their ability to predict why, when, and how someone smoke. What factors influence Korean smokers’ decision to smoke or not? Can Ecological Momentary Assessment (EMA) advance Korean smoking research, and psychological science, the way it did in the West? To answer these questions, I collaborated with Dr. Sooyeon Suh of Sungshing Women’s University, a clinical psychologist with behavioral medicine expertise. My EMA experiment aimed to use mobile devices to measure the mood, thoughts, surrounding, and smoking of 21 smokers in Seoul (see Abstract for details).

Due to the IRB approval timeline, the experiment did not commence during the EAPSI timeframe. However, Dr. Suh’s team and mine continued to collaborate after I left Korea. We finished collecting data from 20 smokers in February, 2016. This report documents the major goals we accomplished during EAPSI.

Smoking. After selecting measures that reflect the most updated evidence consensus, Dr. Suh’s team and I worked extensively to translate the ones that were unavailable in Korean. For this project, my advisor Dr. Andrew Waters and I previously constructed the Reasons for Smoking Decision (RSD) questions for use in the 4 times/day field assessments. The RSD-Smoking presents the most common smoking reasons (e.g., craving, boredom), and asks the person to identify the most influential one right before smoking the most recent cigarette. The RSD-Resist presents the most common reasons to resist the urge to smoke (e.g., no-smoking area, attractiveness), and asks the person to choose analogously to RSD-Smoking.

We worked to adapt the RSD options to reflect relevant Korean factors. We reviewed factors that were within a smoker’s conscious awareness (“I’m irritated”), some were semi-conscious (“My friend offered it”), some required prior planning (“I forgot to bring perfume to hide the smell”), and some were due to Confucianist social etiquettes (“The older person I’m with offered me one”). Factors insignificant to an American’s smoking decision may be pivotal to a Korean smoker, such as being around older or more senior peers, hanging at a noraebang, eating alone, or being female, etc. To capture these Korea-specific factors, we modified the RSD and EMA context questions accordingly, e.g., “where are you,” “who are you with”).

EMA and Psychological Research. I trained and supervised four team members: one graduate student, one undergraduate student, and two unaffiliated Bachelor-level assistants. The training topics included: psychological research design, EMA methodology, research workflow management, psychometric principles, equivalence of functions in translating words, biological-psychological-social factors underlying substance use vs. misuse, programming of the Personal Digital Assistant (PDA) app, interpretation of the app’s debug log (record of user-device interaction), and interview skills with research participants.  I trained the staff on how to set up the PDAs and app, and conduct the phone screening and two lab visits with participants. Each person observed me demonstrate 1 – 2 rounds of the procedures they were assigned. They also completed 1 – 2 full rehearsals (with all equipment and materials) with lab mates who had not been exposed to the experiment yet.
